column1: # SOURCE: Synthetic data for community agri-PV model
# DESCRIPTION: Land use allocation for 25 km2 (2500 ha) community in Sinai Peninsula
# LOGIC: Farmland is primary productive use at 500 ha (20% of total)
# LOGIC: Housing sized for ~150 people in ~35 households at typical rural density
# LOGIC: Ground-mounted solar separate from agri-PV (which is integrated with farmland)
# LOGIC: Roads follow rural community standards (~3-4% of developed area)
# LOGIC: Buffer zones provide separation between land uses and protect from desert encroachment
# LOGIC: Undeveloped land serves as reserve for future expansion and natural desert ecosystem
# ASSUMPTIONS: Hot arid climate requires larger buffer zones for dust and heat management
# ASSUMPTIONS: Solar arrays sized to support community energy needs (~100-150 kW ground-mounted)
# ASSUMPTIONS: Housing density ~4 households per hectare (rural Egyptian standard)

column4: Irrigated cropland for tomato potato onion kale and cucumber production. Suitable for agri-PV installation overhead. Drip irrigation throughout.
Residential housing for ~150 people in ~35 households plus community buildings (school clinic storage). Rural density with small gardens.
Ground-mounted photovoltaic arrays separate from agri-PV. Dedicated solar farm for community electricity supplementing agri-PV production.
Unpaved and paved roads connecting farms to processing facilities and main highway. Includes water distribution infrastructure and power lines.
Vegetated windbreaks and dust barriers between land use types. Desert-adapted species for erosion control and microclimate improvement.
Crop processing buildings including packaging warehouse canning facility and drying equipment. Cold storage for perishables.
Water treatment plant brackish water intake desalination facility water storage tanks and distribution pumping stations.
Undeveloped desert land serving as reserve for future community expansion. Natural desert ecosystem with potential for future agricultural or energy development.
